111.content:
Exploring one of Sunnydale's dozen-something cemeteries usually involved finding a vampire--at least one vampire--in every one. Buffy had done a quick five-minute sweep of this one and had found nothing. She didn't hear anything unusual or see any signs of violence. Satisfied, she headed for the exit, ready for home, bed . . . and probably homework that she had forgotten about until just now.
Actually, this patrol had been unusually unproductive. She dusted a few vampires earlier but things had been so quiet afterwards that Willow and Xander had gone home and she spent the rest of the evening relaxing, strolling from crypt to crypt and finding nothing.
As she left movement caught her eye towards some graves away from the exit. It was a round, dark shape, somewhat humanoid, but awkwardly lumbering over something on the ground. Disgusting gulping sounds came from the shape. It didn't look like a vampire, but Buffy still readied her stake and walked towards it.
"Finally," she said, "I'd hate for this night to be a total bust."
The creature heard as she approached, and stood tall on its two flabby legs. At first, Buffy thought it was fat, but when it lumbered towards her the thing was more of a giant, walking water balloon, filled with some kind of gelatinous slime that gurgled around as it walked. Its hands were like big useless paws. It's head more of a large bump coming off of its smooth shoulders, with a round mouth with a few dozen tiny sharp teeth, and two black, beady eyes.
It pointed a pudgy finger at Buffy as it spoke in what she assumed was anger.
"Glurb glooog gozareth!" it said, or some approximate of that in a slow, deep voice. Spittle of blue slime flew from its mouth at it spoke, flying far enough to spatter Buffy.
"Sorry, I don't speak ugly blob, but maybe if you slow down and speak louder I'll understand what you're saying." With one fluid movement she had her stake away and was leaping off a tombstone, kicking the demon in its chest before it could react. It was too soft, though. It reeled backwards, rolling its arms to keep balance, but Buffy was hurled to the ground rather than being able to launch herself back to a standing position like she normally would.
"A-goorga!" the thing said, apparently even angrier.
"Yeah, agoorga's right," Buffy leaped to her feet.
The thing bellowed, slime flying from its mouth. Buffy grimaced as it hit her again.
"Um, gross. You might--"
"Slorsh!" it yelled, opening its mouth wide and spraying a bucketful of the slime all over Buffy. She blocked some with her arms, and dodged backwards to avoid most of it. Her good fighting jeans might be ruined after that, she thought.
"Hey! What'd I ever--" she started, turning back to the creature. It was already on her, the slime nothing but a distraction. She threw up an elbow to hit it in the face and it bit her arm, creating tiny puncture wounds that didn't really hurt that much. Although, it ruined her sweater. That was an entire ensemble ruined by this thing.
The elbow thrust did connect, though, with the creature's head flying backwards, taking its body with it.
"Shlubba guga!" it said, awkwardly trying to remain standing.
"Ouch! Watch what you do with those things," Buffy said, kneeing the demon in its giant, blobby gut as it fell backwards. She stepped off of it and came down hard on its head. It apparently had no bones, since Buffy squished it flat, disgusting blue slime exploded out all over her boots.
She looked down as the demon stopped moving, what with its head smashed.
"And there go the boots," she said. The creature's body quivered and began shrinking, the slime that filled it evaporating, or vanishing. Within seconds all that was left was skin as Buffy stood over the body, holding her tiny arm wounds.
"Not sure how something like that survived in the wild," she said, preparing to leave. This body was clearly going to take care of itself and wouldn't need disposal.
As Buffy walked out of the cemetery she felt queasy and blamed the bite, wondering if it was venomous. Her stomach was groaning, feeling sick and full. It came on her so suddenly that she had to stop and steady herself on the cemetery gate. She hunched over, he arm wrapped around her stomach. She moaned as pain and pressure grew inside her.

Buffy woke that Saturday morning feeling off. Showering, brushing her teeth, combing her hair, didn't help. She didn't both putting on anything more than sweatpants and a tank top to go downstairs for breakfast. Her slayer energy, she figured, just wasn't with her today.
Things hadn't been easy lately. Her friends were still getting used to her return after Angel's death. The new slayer Faith was less than helpful despite her noninfectious enthusiasm. It's no wonder she was so tired and sluggish.
Dawn was already awake, almost done eating three of the large pile of pancakes on the table.
"Hey, where's mom?" Buffy asked as she got herself a plate.
"She's at the gallery," Dawn said. "It's like 11:00."
Buffy's stomach growled, making her realize just how hungry she was. She sat down and, without a second thought, just pulled the entire stack of pancakes to her.
"Hey, some of those are mine!" Dawn said.
"You have yours," Buffy said, her mouth already full with her first bite while she poured syrup on with her free hand. She didn't even both to cut them, just cutting the entire stack into large bite fulls with her fork and shoving them in her face. She was ravenous. Her mind suddenly fixated on the task of getting these pancakes into her stomach.
"I'm going over to Tiffany's," Dawn said. She spoke some more, probably detailing her plans for the day, but Buffy wasn't listening. She was eating. And eating. And eating.
In less than a minute she had demolished the stack of a ten pancakes. Dawn rolled her eyes.
"You're not even listening to me," she said and stood up.
"Mmm?" Buffy swallowed.
"What are you doing today?" Dawn said, trying to take an interest. She was getting old enough now that Buffy's slayer duties were holding more than a casual interest to her. She was thinking that soon, maybe, Buffy would let her in, let her help.
"I dunno'. I'll check to see if Giles has anything for me to do," Buffy stood up and went to the fridge. There wasn't any food readily available, just cold cuts, drinks, ingredients. If she wanted food, she'd either have to eat or drink it straight, or prepare it herself. She was just so hungry right now. Her stomach, full from breakfast, stilled growled at her, demanding more food. And she wanted it now.

The rational part of Buffy's brain told her she had just had a full breakfast. She couldn't possibly be this hungry. A drink was in order to wash it down. That's what her rumbling stomach wanted, she thought. There was a gallon of milk, almost full. As Dawn watched with part awe and part disgust, Buffy opened the jug and began drinking.
And drinking.
And drinking.
She closed her eyes as she poured the milk into her mouth. She felt her full, growling stomach growing cool as it filled with milk. She rubbed it gently as she drank, the rhythmic glug glug glug sound hypnotic. Her stomach whirled and growled under her hand, growing fuller with each gulp.
"Um, Buffy?" she heard her sister say, but ignored her. The very act of filling her stomach seemed to put her into a trance. She only started coming out of it as she approached the end of the carton. A dull ache was spreading through her cold, stuffed stomach. She became conscious that her hand was no longer feeling the flat stomach she was used to, but instead a gentle curve. A hard, bulging curve that pressed out into her sweat pants, riding her shirt up enough to expose her taut tummy to the world. It was starting to hurt now. She grasped her stomach with her free hand harder and moaned. She couldn't stop until she finished the carton. It didn't make any sense, but that's how she felt.
Finally, nearly an entire carton of milk was gone, vanished into her tiny, impossibly full stomach.
She belched so loudly it could be heard throughout the house. She wiped her mouth and wobbled in place. She put the empty carton back in the fridge and looked down to see what her hand was already feeling.
Her tummy peaked out from beneath her shirt. It was pushing out several inches, a hard, alien dome on her otherwise tight, slim body.
She pressed it gently with both hands. The cold feeling was dissipating, replaced with an uncomfortable, almost painful sensation of a belly stretched beyond human limits.
She belched again, unable to speak yet.
"What the heck, Buffy?" Dawn was more annoyed than mystified. She was used to her sister occasionally showing bizarre bursts of appetite, which she attributed to her slayer nature.
"Why did I do that?" Buffy asked, turning unsteadily to her sister, both hands still firmly on her engorged tummy.
With difficulty she lowered herself into the chair and leaned back. She winced both from pain and from the sight of her bloated stomach sticking out.
Then it growled again, followed by another giant belch. Buffy moaned, leaning her head back. She was still hungry.
"Are you okay?" Dawn asked.
Buffy had to gather her thoughts before she answered.

When Giles, Willow, and Xander stormed into the Summers house they didn't know what to expect. Vampires wouldn't be out in broad daylight like this. Demons might be, but everything felt normal. What they were not expecting to find was Buffy lying on the kitchen floor surrounded by discarded bags, cartons, and crumbs. She looked asleep but her breathing was heavy, which made sense considering how stuffed she was.

"Oh my god," Giles said softly as he knelt down next to her. They gathered that she had been eating, but no normal person could eat this much. No stomach, or the skin around it, could stretch as much as Buffy's had. She didn't look full, she looked pregnant. Her stomach towered over her, round and tight. There were stretch marks forming along her sides, and her belly button had popped out.

"What happened to her?" Xander asked.

"Did she . . . eat all everything?" Willow asked unbelieving as she looked at the empty cabinets.

"Buffy?" Giles said. He reached out a hand and touched her stomach. It was tight, painfully so, and her insides turned with a juicy gurgle.

Buffy's eyes shot open with a gasp, she grabbed her stomach.

"Ooh, that hurts!" she yelled. Giles yanked his hand away.

Buffy struggled to pull herself into a seating position, but only managed to do so halfway by leaning against the fridge. She blushed despite herself.

"Well, this happened," she aid simply.

"What happened?" Giles asked.

"I ate it all. Everything. I couldn't stop. I knew I was full, but I just couldn't. The only thing that stopped was that I think I-bwuuuurp-passed out," she moaned and rubbed her stomach. It hurt just to touch it.

"We should regroup at my house," Giles said. "Can you stand?"

Buffy tried. She gripped the cabinet and stood up, but the weight was too much. She felt the sides of her stomach straining, as though her stomach as going to fall out. She yelped in pain and sat back down.

"Oh no, I don't think . . . I don't think I can stand on my own," she said, her worry finally showing. "What's happening to me?"

"Willow, a little help," Giles and Willow lifted Buffy. She had to grip her stomach tightly.

"It feels like I'm going to explode," she said between breaths and burps, "Am I going to explode?"

"I wouldn't think so," Giles said as they moved her to the den.

"I think if this is a spell it's taking into account that you'd get this, ah, full," Willow said. "I think anyone who wasn't a slayer would have passed out from exhaustion before you did. So, um, yay for you?"

"Yeah, I'm real impressive," Buffy huffed.

"Who did it?" Xander asked.

"I think first we need to stop it," Giles said. Buffy's belly was gurgling and churning loudly. She winced in pain.

"I-I'm still hungry, guys."

"I think you've had enough," Willow said trying to lighten the mood.

"Willow and I will get the bottom of this. Xander, you clean up-"

"Oh, come on! really?" Xander said, looking at the mess. "I am in a stabbing mood, not a cleaning one."

"Xander, please just do it," Willow said. "And maybe leave a note."

"'Dear Ms. Summers, Daughter fat now. More news later,''" Buffy said with what breath she could muster. She took a blanket from the couch and wrapped it around herself as they passed. The last thing she wanted was neighborhood rumors about how Joyce's problem child got herself knocked up. Willow started to helpfully pull her shirt down somewhat, but Buffy yelped and pushed her hand away.

"It's too tight to touch," she said simply.

The three left Xander alone. He shrugged, and commenced to cleaning as well as he knew how.

"Lay me in the back seat," Buffy said, "Having trouble-uurp-bending in the middle right now."

They complied. The ride was comfortable for none of them. Every bump or turn of Giles' car caused her stomach to go into an uproar, and noises weren't pleasant for those just listening either.

"Don't worry, Buffy, we can fix this. You'll be good as new and not all stuffed in no time," Willow said, although she certainly looked worried.

"Oooh, I believe you but just hurry, okay?" she said, holding her belly as tight as she could. It was like her insides were struggling to get out, and the weight was causing her hips and back to ache even lying down.

In their months together, Willow made Tara feel more special than she ever had before. She had grown in confidence and assertiveness since they met. She had gotten over a lot of the hang ups she had from her upbringing. She was learning to be herself. She didn't feel so bad about being shy, and didn't mind not being as up to par in her magical studies as Willow was.
Still, Willow was learning a lot. Her skills were growing each day. It didn't seem liker her love for Tara was diminishing, but one thing was now causing Tara to doubt herself. She felt her meek, mousy personality taking over again, and felt even worse at the reason.
Tara was gaining weight.
It was a little at first, as much as any college freshman might. Since usually wore clothes that didn't show off her figure it wasn't noticable at first. But now she was outgrowing things. She was getting a regular potbelly. Her face was growing puffy, her cheeks bloating up. Her ass and hips were especially feeling the brunt of her indulgence as she looked in the mirror one day and discovered that she was officially wide.
She moaned, a pouty expression on her pudgy face.
Willow, still slender, looking beautiful in something as simple as a flowing skirt and t-shirt, looked around the door, smiling. Tara's heart sank when she saw the smile fade, replaced by an obviously force one.
"Whats up, sweetie?" Willow asked entering the room.
Tara, almost in tears, spread her arms.
"I'm fat. I'm just . . . fat."
Willow hugged her. Her hands avoided the newly developed rolls of fat on her back, and her increasingly flabby ass.
"Oh, Tara, you're not fat, you're . . ." Willow didn't finish the sentence fast enough. "Well, you're beautiful and I love you and you know that, right?"
Tara sniffed. She could tell that as much as putting on this weight bothered her, it bothered Willow, too. That she knew Willow was ashamed that it bothered her didn't make it sting any less. Willow had never thought about Tara's body until she started growing. Then she tried ignoring it. She was ashamed of herself. It seemed so superficial of her, but she couldn't help it. Willow admitted to herself that she liked her women like she liked her men, thin and fit, or at least small, even if she wouldn't say that to Tara.
The occasional goading to go for a walk with her, and some vague references to using the college gym, didn't help. Tara knew they were aimed at her. And Willow knew she'd have to get used to having a fat girlfriend.
"I . . . I know you find me less attractive now--" Tara started, as she tugged on the shirt hugging her round belly.
"Aw, sweetie, no--"
"I know you do, it's true, don't lie," Tara said it sadly, not accusing, not blaming.
"Tara, it's just that . . ." Willow didn't know what to say now that it was almost out in the open.
Tara ran past Willow, shoving aside her hand.
"Tara, wait," Willow started after her.
"Don't," Tara said. "I have to go think, okay? Just leave me alone for now."
"O-okay . . ." Willow said as Tara left.
She sat on the bed, confused, upset, depressed. She'd give Tara a few hours. A little weight shouldn't be anything to get so upset over, anyways, Willow told herself. Although secretly she was embarrassed to admit she hoped Tara was out doing something about her gain.

Tara.

And even that rode up on her stomach, exposing a dimpled naval she did not want to be constantly reminded of.

I'm all belly, Willow thought with a frown, her newfound double chin spreading out as she looked down at the bulbous gut spreading into her lap. It's not that her thighs weren't thicker, or that her ass hadn't ballooned in its own right, but it was definitely her belly that was bugging Willow the most. It had gained proportionally the most weight. She almost wished that, whatever Tara had done, she could have at least gotten some extra flab in her breasts and hips.

That thought made her more depressed.

The door opened. Willow cringed as she saw Tara's expression. She slowly walked towards her fattened girlfriend, her hands going up to her mouth, unable to speak at first. Willow managed a feint smile and shrugged. It almost seemed funny now. Willow had only recently developed a fear of getting fat, and now right on cue, here was the heavier, flabbier Willow.

"This is my fault," was all Tara could say. She began crying. It made Willow feel better. She knew it wasn't intentional, but the anger only completely dissipated when she saw Tara's reaction. Willow, with some difficult, heaved herself up and went to her. They embraced, both feeling extremely self-conscious about her their larger figures.

"I'm so sorry, I never meant for this to happen," Tara said. "I just wanted to be thin, like you, and . . . and . . ."

"I know, honey, I know. It was an accident," Willow avoided saying more. She was enough in the right mind to know that telling Tara how disgusting and blubbery she felt might be taken the wrong way.

Willow stepped back to look her in the eyes. They both smiled, finding themselves in the same predicament.

Against her better nature, Tara now had a new appreciation for how hard it was for Willow to watch her gain weight. As much as she wanted to focus on getting Willow back to normal, Tara couldn't help but realize just how much less attractive she found Willow now. It was a fleeting thought--although it returned briefly as Tara's eyes involuntarily eyed Willow's puffy cheeks or round, full belly.

"I'll fix this. I promise, Willow," Tara said with a resolve Willow had rarely heard in her voice.

"Let's hit the books," Willow said, trying to sound perky despite knowing she was looking anything but.

But Tara was already at it. She reached out her hand and, as a burst of hot air blew between them, spoke.

"Let this be reversed!" she said.

"Wait!" Willow shouted, but it was too late. Tara had spoken, and in her haste had essentially just thrown magic at the problem with no prior thought.

Willow stepped backwards from the force, her hands were on her belly. It felt full, and active, and the feeling was spreading. She yelped as she felt her stomach stretching into her hands. One, two, three inches, it pressed outward, her shirt riding up even further, her lovehandles becoming a full belt of fat as the sensation spread.

Blorp. Her belly actually went 'blorp,' Willow thought, squealing as her body spiraled out of control.

She grabbed her sides, they puffed out. Her hips and ass expanded even, stretching her sweatpants to become form-fitting. When the tingling reached her breasts, she grabbed for those too, and felt only a slight stretching of her bra.

"Tara!" Willow shouted in fear as the last of the weight finally settled on her face, already swollen from before.

It was done. Another ten, fifteen pounds on her already chubbified self. She didn't even want to look in the mirror at the damage. She could tell be the weight pulling her down, by how she had to spread her legs more to stand, that she had surpassed chubby and was now fat. Officially fat.

Willow whined, holding her flabbier gut in despair, and then was speechless.

Tara had experienced something else. She felt a pleasant, sucking feeling throughout her body, like a great weight was being lifted from her physically and spiritually. Her hands moved to her belly as it shrunk, rubbed her hips as they narrowed. She was still large, but, as she turned to the mirror her feeling of ecstasy coming down to a comfortable joy.

Her shirt was no longer too tight, but complimented her soft curves nicely. Her dress had fallen a little, her belly and ass no longer forcing it up higher on her waste. And her face, that was the best. She smiled and didn't feel disgusted with how she looked. She was still larger than when she started college, but she was smaller, and it just felt so good that it barely registered exactly what had happened to those excess pounds.

As great as her new body felt, she knew it wouldn't last. She would be forced to willing stuff herself for weeks, months, until she could be even with Willow.

Honestly, she thought it was a fitting punishment for what she had done, but it didn't make the idea anymore appealing.

She found a quiet Chinese buffet which her and Willow had been to before. The owners probably didn't recognize her, or if they did it was such a slow, lazy part of the day that they dispensed with their usual pleasant greetings. Tara found a seat, found her first plate, and filled it.

All she knew was if she didn't meet up with Willow later absolutely stuffed she would be in for some serious guilt.

How much more before I can say I'm done? she wondered. She rubbed her tummy. She rubbed it like she was saying goodbye to a new friend she didn't have enough time with. She frowned, groaning out loud.

She was starting to look as bloated as she felt, her stomach gently rising and pressing into the elastic band of her skirt. When she leaned forward and found she had to work at it, Tara realized that enough was enough. Maybe she would eat more tomorrow, but the thought of more food now was making her nauseous, and nausea was the last thing her painfully swollen gut needed right now.

Willow was already on the other side of two-hundred pounds, and if she didn't lose any weight at all, Tara would have to be there, too. She would have be as fat as she made Willow.

Dawn and Tiffany sat on the comfortable couch, surrounded by their potential sisters-to-be, who chattered away, asked about their families and their interests, and complimented their outfits. Tiffany soaked up the attention, but Dawn only felt her suspicions growing. Jenna had "pretended" to mistake her Sears jeans for designer originals -- and she was sure anyone so elegant and fashion-conscious would never make such a mistake. She was being buttered up.

All the potential new sisters here were, she realized. The few girls who weren't already members were surrounded by knots of Kappas laughing and cooing over them and keeping their plates topped off with mountains of greasy, fattening treats. She and Tiffany were no exception; they hadn't even had to get off the couch, because the Kappas had just kept piling on more pizza, and more chips, and more soda, and more and more and more. Half an hour into the party, Dawn was so stuffed with junk she was beginning to feel slightly sick.

"D'you always eat like this?" she asked, looking down wearily at yet another parmesan-crusted hunk of Crazy Bread. "I mean, you guys don't look like you live on pizza."

Jenna smiled and arched her back, emphasizing her slender waist and pert chest. "Let's just say we know a few little stay-slim secrets that work exceptionally well."

"You don't stick your fingers down your throats, or--" Dawn began. Tiffany elbowed her in the side.

"Dawn!" she scolded. "Of course they don't." She looked up at Jenna apologetically. "Sorry about Dawn. I would love to hear your secret!"

Jenna laughed. "Well, it is a secret, dear. But when -- if you're invited to join us, I promise you you'll find all about it firsthand."

There was a commotion from across the room. Dawn's head turned in time to see one of the groups of Kappas backing away from a girl she recognized as another potential pledge -- a short, stocky girl with chocolate-brown hair. She had one hand on her stomach and another clamped over her mouth.

"Bathroom!" she groaned. "I gotta -- I'm gonna--"

One of the Kappas, her face twisted with a look of disgust, pointed the girl to the far hall. The sick girl staggered across the room, disappearing into the darkness.

"Oh, well that's a shame," Jenna said, shaking her head. "Ate too much, I suppose. I hope she manages to keep it off the carpet."

Maybe if you weren't practically force-feeding us, Dawn thought. "I guess not everyone has the stomach to be a Kappa, huh?"

Jenna chuckled again. "You know, that's a very good way of putting it. We do like to find sisters who can put their money where their mouth is, so to speak."

Tiffany -- who had to have eaten at least as much as Dawn had -- widened her eyes and stuffed another piece of pizza into her mouth. "I 'ike e'ain," she mumbled around the wad of dough. "Mmmm!"

The chubby girl spoke up, and Dawn realized it was the first thing she'd heard her say. "That's right, you know," she said dreamily. "That's why they wanted me. I won the pie-eating event at Springfest last year. See?"

She flicked her finger across the screen of her phone, bringing up a picture of a several people behind a table covered in empty pie tins. Dawn took a closer look. Sure enough, there was the girl, grinning face plastered with pie filling -- about forty pounds less of her. She was practically svelte. She'd really packed in on over the summer. Which was funny, when you thought about it, because she was the only girl here who wasn't stuffing her face...

"Do you want the rest of my food?" Dawn asked. "I don't think I can finish this."

"Oh, no," the girl said hurriedly. "I'm ... I'm not hungry." Her features darkened, and a half-formed worry wrinkled her forehead. "Besides, I think I'm gaining weight. Especially since ... since most of the girls came back from summer break... it's almost like--"

"Oh, don't be silly, Lindsay, you look great!" Jenna said hastily. "Doesn't she? Doesn't she just look amazing?"

The other Kappas were quick to agree, soothing Lindsay and showering her with compliments.

Something definitely stinks here, Dawn thought. And I'm going to find out what it is. And to do that, I'll need them to like me. And they like big eaters... She picked up her grease-soaked plate again. Sorry, stomach. You'll just have to suck it up.
141211.title: Key to the Kappas

choices: They both join, Dawn only to investigate their schemes
Tiffany joins, but Dawn refuses, saying she has to think about it
1412111.content:
Two hours of stuffing and schmoozing and Dawn was still not entirely sure something supernatural was happening. Of course, she was certain that some shenanigans were afoot, but she was careful about jumping the gun. In Sunnydale, she already would have decided that, yes, the Kappas were fattening up new members to stay thin themselves, but outside of the Hellmouth that kind of hypothesis would be less and less likely.
On the one hand, no outside force was compelling her or Tiffany to stuff themselves. And then on the other, the Kappas were eating more than them constantly and didn't even look full. Meanwhile, Dawn wasn't sure she could stand. Both her and Tiffany slouched back in the absurdly comfortable couch, hands on their full, hard tummies, diligently accepting food and conversation from passing Kappas.
Jenna was with them almost the entire time. Each of the potential pledges had a few girls hanging around them, making sure they stayed stuffed. They others slowed down as the night went on, each taking seat and not getting up while they stuffed their faces with anything the Kappas gave them. Dawn wanted to ask Tiffany about what she thought. Surely by now even Tiffany's enthusiasm would have waned in light of the feast resting inside her.
Then Ellen, the hyper blonde ballerina Dawn remembered from the cafeteria, gave her a break.
". . . of course you'd be living in our house, Tiffany, that's how sororities work," Jenna answered Tiffany. "We have plenty of room. More than we used to, I'm sorry to say."
"A lot less--uurp--members these days?" Dawn said lazily, barely stifling a soft belch as she self-consciously rested her hands on her stuffed stomach.
"Sadly, it's true," Jenna said, then added quickly, "I think our standard's have gotten higher, perhaps. Or maybe Greek societies aren't as popular as they used to be, what with the economy and all."
Tiffany nodded with a mouth full. Dawn had given up eating, only picking at a plate full of greasy, cheesy nachos another Kappa had left next to her.
"Just makes it more exclusive," Tiffany nodded and then swallowed. She leaned forward, her smile as bright as at the start of the evening if her eyes were heavy. She opened her mouth to speak and then blushed bright red as the button snapped off her jeans. She paused, waiting for a reaction.
Jenna just laughed and went on. Dawn just stared, wide-eyed, as Tiffany went on as if nothing happened as well. Dawn figured she was on the verge of busting a button herself.
"Jenna!" Ellen ran up and grabbed her friend's hand, "Where's Chelsea?"
"The brunette who threw up all over the bathroom over an hour ago? I think she left," Jenna said. "Just couldn't stomach it," she chuckled to Dawn and Tiffany. Tiffany robotically laughed back.
"Damn it! Damn it!" Ellen said, stomping her foot in a cartoony fashion. "Any other pledges left?"
"Oh, well--"
Lindsey hadn't said a word in over an hour, just leaned against the wall by Dawn, staring dreamily into space. At one point she began rubbing her soft stomach and didn't stop. She was now hunched over, grasping her belly tightly. To Dawn it looked even bigger than before, rounder even. She heard a painful gurgle from inside while Lindsey winced. The zipper along the side of her skirt had begun sliding down, Dawn now noticed. It was like over the course of the night her stomach, if not the rest of her, was growing fuller despite her not eating a thing.
"Ooooooh," Lindsey moaned.
Jenna stood at attention, "Lindsey? What's wrong?"
Lindsey moaned again, hunching forward, cradling her now pregnant-looking belly. Her shirt didn't even fully cover it now. Dawn attempted to stand and offer a hand, but found her own fullness keeping her weighted to the spot. She couldn't move fast enough before Lindsey bolted as fast as she could.
"Something's . . . wrong . . . " she said as she scuttled off.
"Lindsey? Lindsey?" Jenna said. She turned to Dawn, "Poor thing. She has a gluten allergy. It must have just hit her. I'll go see if she's okay."
Lindsey ran to the bathroom, or rather waddled. Jenna followed, as did Ellen, finally leaving Dawn alone with Tiffany.
"Okay, Tiffany, let's get out of her," she said, shifting into a sitting rather than slouching position. Her jeans dug into her stuffed tummy uncomfortably. Tiffany shamelessly remained slouching, her jeans popped open, still munching on a chicken leg.
"What, why? I haven't eaten this good in months! And that Jenna is so cool, I hope she's out sorority boss person thingy."
"Are you serious? Tiff, I've been pumping her for information for two hours and she's evaded every question and flat out made stuff up the whole time. And everybody is being way too nice for this to be normal."
Dawn thought she'd keep any fears of magical happenings to herself. Tiffany was never in the know about Dawn or her sister's world. Like most of the former inhabitants of Sunnydale, Tiffany kept herself in intentional ignorance.
"Are you suspicious because they're actually nice and not a bunch of nasty airheads like you thought they'd be?"
"It's not that, it's--Tiffany, look at this," Dawn motioned to her stomach, so full it actually looked rounder. Then she motioned to Tiffany's equally bloated midsection. "We're going to explode if we eat anymore. For the sake of our figures, let's call this a night."
"You two!" Jenna returned. She looked nervous but kept up a cheerful disposition as always. "So, night's winding down. Everyone had a good time. I hope you two are okay?"
"Fantastic!" Tiffany said.
"A little full . . ." Dawn said, no longer hiding the suspicious tone she originally took with them.
"That is just great. You two are definitely Kappa material."
"So, um, do you discuss it and then let us know if we're in?" Tiffany asked hopefully.
"We'll do you one better, dear. You can join tonight if you want. You'll just have to sign the vow of secrecy, there will be a little ceremony, and then you're in. Kappa for life, and all." Jenna was smiling much wider than Dawn thought appropriate. Looking around, she realized that only one other potential member was left--a slim, serious-looking Indian girl who held her own when it came to eating.
"We'd be honored to have you as part of our sisterhood. Are you in?" Jenna was asking Dawn more than Tiffany, since Tiffany was obviously willing to do anything she was told.
1412111.title: All night buffet, no standing required

choices: She tries to get one of the other girls alone for questioning.
She bides her time, waiting to see what will happen.
14121111.content:
"Sure," Dawn said with a smile. "I'm in."

Jenna beamed. "That's great!" She grabbed Dawn in a big bear hug and squeezed. Dawn didn't know which was more uncomfortable -- the pressure on her overfull stomach, or the way Tiffany awkward tried to insert herself into the hug.

It's a tie, she decided eventually.

"Well, then, there's no need to wait. We'll get you made official Kappas and then you can crash here tonight. It'll be just like a great big slumber party!"

Dawn had to fight the urge to roll her eyes, and wondered if she'd made the right decision. Every slumber party she'd ever been to had involved large amounts of food, and the thought of more eating was distinctly unappealing.

"Let me just have a quick word with the others," Jenna said, turning to the room and clapping her hands. "Okay, Kappas! We have some new pledges here and we're going to conduct the ceremony in just a moment--"

There was a chorus of cheers and some enthusiastic clapping from the girls; Dawn could swear she heard at least one of them say "Finally!"

"--but first, a couple of reality checks for you all," Jenna continued. "First, right now Lindsay is on her way to the emergency room. No, no, hold your gasps, she'll be fine. But I wouldn't expect her to return. I realize Lindsay played a vital role in our sorority and I know a lot of you put a lot of pressure on her, more than one girl could be expected to take. I expect you all to treat our new pledges with respect and care. That means no piling on more than they can handle, especially not tonight. I think we can agree they're all partied out."

There was a general mutter of acceptance, but people weren't happy. Dawn noticed Melanie, the Hawaiian-looking girl she'd met earlier, dropping a half-eaten chicken breast back onto her plate with a scowl, and several of the other girls were emptying their plates into the trash.

Jenna opened a door in the paneling and motioned the new pledges through. The stairway on the other side was dank, narrow, and smelled of earth.

"It's just a root cellar," Jenna said soothingly. "There's better light down there. Come on."

The three new pledges followed her -- Dawn trying not to let her suspicions show too obviously, Tiffany beaming with joy, and the quiet Indian girl looking so nervous her knees might start knocking together at any moment. Dawn felt bad for her. She wanted to yell, run! Get out of the house while you still can!

Then again, she wouldn't if she wouldn't soon regret not taking her own advice.

At the bottom of the staircase was a circular stone room which had to be well below ground level. In the center of the room sat a statue. It was massive, carved from rough reddish-white stone with striations that made it look like the surface of Jupiter, and shaped like some sort of gibbering creature --

Then the blindfold went on. Dawn gasped. "Sorry -- you're not a sister yet!" Jenna said into her ear. "Now, we'll prick your finger and you just sign your name--"

Oh, because this isn't a bad sign or anything, Dawn thought sarcastically, smearing her bloody fingertip across what felt like parchment. She doubted it would be legible even if she had been able to see what she was doing.

"And now, the ceremony. Girls, don't worry about what your hear. This is all just for fun." Jenna's voice dropped suddenly. "Alixiin! Moralasque! Piru! We call on your strength. Manifest and be made true!"

Dawn felt a blast of hot air on her face. She wished she could see what was happening.

"Now, Tiffany, Dawn, Tamisa, raise your right hands. Everyone else, repeat after me.

I take these three to be my sisters.
What sustains me, shall sustain them in my place;
I ask only what I need to live

The assembled Kappas repeated the oath in a dull roar. Every single one of them must be in here, Dawn realized.

Let them blossom where I wither
Let them be granted the abundance of all of us
And let what we take and do not need, be given to them instead.
Kamlatchimarazon!


The Kappas clapped their hands together, two short, sharp claps in unison, and the furnace heat dissipated.
Dawn felt something smooth and cool being placed against her lips; a ceramic bowl. Obligingly -- she could hardly stop now -- she drank, though she felt like she was about to burst. Her painfully full stomach strained against her jeans. The liquid was salty and sweet, and probably would have been quite delicious under other circumstances.

The blindfold was ripped off her head and Jenna was grinning at her. "All done! You guys are Kappas now!"

"So can I look at the--" Dawn began, but Jenna and Melanie were on either side of her, spinning her around and practically dragging her back towards the steps.

"What was all that stuff about blossoming and giving your stuff to me and all of that?" she persisted.

"Oh, it's just a stupid old poem. Silly, I know," Jenna said with a shrug, "but it's tradition! Now, come out, let's get out of this smelly old basement. I'll show you to your rooms!"

Dawn wanted to press further, but she already felt so stuffed and lethargic that she could barely keep her eyes open.
Fine, bed, she thought, but tomorrow, answers!
14121111.title: Welcome to the House

Melanie stays mum, this new kid's asking too many questions for her own good
141211111.content:
Jenna didn't find holding back from eating any easier than the other girls did, but she did it. The next morning, though, she finally indulged. She had three frozen pizzas in her fridge waiting for her. She ate one. Only with great strength of will did she resist from eating the others. There was a lot of work to be done. Now was not the time to be celebrating. They lost one sister and gained three. They were still far behind.

With that mindset, Jenna went down to the social around ten and was extremely pissed off to find most of her fellow Kappas lounging around stuffing their faces. She wasn't so much disgusted by the fact that they were casually eating leftover food that had been sitting out all night--they had the same insatiable hunger as her, and it didn't care what the food was--but that she had been fighting so hard to not binge for months now and after her constant talks her sisters refused to listen.

"What the hell are you doing?" Jenna stormed in. She tried not to yell, fearing that the new pledges would hear, but that self-restraint was difficult.

"What?" Ellen said, her mouth full. Other girls put their plates down or hid them.

"Okay, okay, I'm calming down now," Jenna gave herself a moment. "Do you know what happened last night?"

"Yeah, we finally got three new mules!" one girl said.

"Yes, we have three now. Now, a lot of you haven't been as studious when it comes to the magical arts as you're expected to be, so let me explain this to you. When you eat, the calories go to our mules. For a house our size we need at least ten. That way, over the course of a semester they might gain fifty, sixty pounds at the most. A lot, but not unrealistic. When we have less than that, they start getting fat too fast. And when we have too few, they don't just absorb the calories, they're stomachs start filling. Lindsey almost exploded last night--"

"I'm trying to eat here!" Melanie said.

"--because you hogs couldn't hold off. We have three mules now. I'd like to keep their growth down to ten pounds at least for the first week, okay? Can you slobs handle that?"

There were a few nods of reluctant agreement. Melanie glared at Jenna and Jenna, eager for a single person to take her frustration out on, took notice.

"Do you have a problem with that, Mel?" Jenna asked.

"No--" Melanie said, but Jenna was already talking like she said 'yes.'

"Maybe you don't understand because you're not a legacy member like most of us. It's not just our figures that we're maintaining here. Beauty is important, yes, but there's more. There's grace. Charisma. Even luck. And it's not just ours. Our mothers, and sisters, cousins, all depend on Kappa houses remaining alive and well. We are the only chapter in the country that's shrinking every year. If we have to close, we won't be the only ones paying for it. No offense, but just because your family is a bunch of obese middle-class failures doesn't mean you can ignore that the rest of us have more riding on this than just our own college careers."

"Hey, we're doing our best, what are you doing other than just bitching at us?" Melanie said.

"Just remember your obligations. I'm the leading sister here. If I think any of you are going to threaten the survival of this chapter, I can put in to have any one of you made into a in-house mule."

"You wouldn't--" Melanie said defiantly.

Jenna spread her hands to Melanie.

"You are released from our protection for one day!" she said.

The look of sheer terror on Melanie's face as priceless.

"That was a blank. Next time I won't hold back," Jenne turned to leave. "Mel can clean up. The rest of you come with me. We have to get these girls moved in and settled into Kappa life."

----------

Dawn awoke feeling full. Maybe even fuller than when she went to sleep. She rubbed her bloated tummy and buttoned her jeans with more effort than she liked. She realized she would have to crack this case in a hurry if she didn't want to become a butterball before the semester was over.

She found herself in one of the Kappa's smaller social rooms, sleeping on a comfortable couch. Apparently she stayed up chatting and--she groaned to herself--eating with the other Kappas for a while before passing out. The new girl was curled up on another couch. Tiffany was lying face up, her visibly swollen stomach popping out for all the world to see.

It was almost noon. Dawn didn't think she'd have time to do any spy work today. But if she could talk to some of the girls one on one, away from Jenna, maybe she could get some information out of them.

She tugged her shirt down and headed for the social hall. She heard movement and was surprised to see only Melanie there. Melanie was not the one Dawn would have chosen. She knew she was close to Jenna, for one thing, and probably loyal. Also, she was on the cheer squad. Dawn didn't even know cheerleading was a sport outside of high school. And her experiences with cheerleaders were either the ones who mocked her for being a weird loner freak in school, or Cordelia during the few times she saw her while her and Xander were dating.

"Good morning," Dawn put on her most cheerful expression as she approached Melanie. Melanie glowered, but then faked a pleasant smile when she saw who it was.

"Hey, Dawn! Glad you're awake. Did you have fun last night? I love breaking in the new sisters," she laughed.

"Yeah, it was a blast," Dawn rubbed her sickeningly full stomach, still managing a smile. "Do you, uh, need any help?"

"That's okay, I volunteered. The others are going to help you three get ready today. You're moving in, so there's that. Also, lots of functions. So many functions."

Something was bothering her. Dawn took a shot.

"Are you okay? You seem like something's bugging you," Dawn asked.
141211111.title: First morning at Kappa house

choices: Dawn tries her luck with a different sister.
Dawn investigates that room downstairs where they were intiated.
1412111112.content:
Melanie wanted to unleash a few choice words about Jenna and her entitled little princess complex. It definitely was no fun being left to clean up after the others; the table looked like it had been attacked by pigs. Filthy, ill-mannered pigs.

Her place was just as messy as the others, of course, but well, that was different.

She wanted to say something, but she held her tongue. If it got back to Jenna, it could be a disaster. She could be made into another mule -- just another calorie sponge for the rest of them to fatten up. She couldn't stand the thought of that happening.

Not again...

---------

Two years ago...

Melanie stomped into Kappa house and flung herself down on the couch, sobbing.

"What's wrong now, Mel? Stub your toe? Break a nail?" her fellow first-year Ellen said, rolling her eyes and taking another huge of bite of her pastrami sandwich. "Mmph -- see a cloud?"

"Ellen," Jenna said warningly.

"Well, it's always just drama, drama, drama with her!"

"Ellen, do I have to tell Jane you were being mean to one of our most valuable members?"

Ellen paled. "You wouldn't dare."

"I would."

"Narc." Ellen made a face, wiped a splotch of sauce on her face, and left. A moment later, Melanie felt Jenna's hand resting on her shoulder.

"Do you want to talk about it?" the sophomore girl asked her kindly.

"N-no," Melanie sniffled. "Ellen's right. It's just stupid drama. You wouldn't be interested."

"I am very interested in keeping you happy. Come on, sweetie. Tell me what's going on."

Melanie looked up at Jenna balefully. "I -- I gained weight again."

"What?" Jenna said, looking shocked. "I could have sworn you'd lost weight. It doesn't show at all! Are you sure!"

"The c-captain could tell. She made me get on the scale in front of everybody, and, a-and I've put on fifteen pounds since coming here."

"Oh, well -- that's just the Freshman Fifteen, everybody gets that--"

"In less than a month? And I only barely made the team as it is." She remembered the way the captain of the squad had tried to eliminate her at the beginning of tryouts -- "Look, Mau, maybe in whatever one-pineapple town you come from they're hard up enough for girls to let chubsters on the squad, but this is the big time, okay?" -- and had only relented because her routine was so good.

"She told me she'd weigh me again in a week," Melanie said, "and if I haven't lost at least five pounds, I'm off the team! I'm never gonna do it. I've been eating nothing but carrot sticks since I got here, but... but I just keep..."

She frowned and grabbed the roll of fat squashing over the waistband of her skirt. "I don't know where this is coming from!"

Jenna gulped down the last bite of Ellen's sandwich. "Well, if they kick you off the team, it's their loss. You can just... spend more time around here, with us! You know how much all the girls love having you around."

Melanie sniffled again. "You've all been so nice to me... and so supportive. I don't know how I'm gonna do it when I have to go home for winter break."

Jenna nodded. "The holidays are hard on all of us."

"My sisters will have a field day when they see how fat I got," Melanie said sourly. "Just because they can eat and eat and never gain a thing."

"Sisters?" Jenna was instantly alert. "How many? How old are they?"

"Five, and I'm the oldest."

"Five? And... you say they have fast metabolisms?"

"Yeah. I don't know why I'm the only one who got screwed. I just know when they go to college, they'll never gain a pound."

"Mm-hmm." Jenna looked thoughtful. "And... what if they did?"

"Huh?"

"Hypothetically, let's say you could arrange it so your sisters would put on a little weight during their college years. Would you do it?"

"Sure, I guess," Melanie said. "I mean, that would be great! But it'll never happen."

Jenna gave Melanie a quick hug. "You know what? I'm going to have a talk with Jane. I think the other sisters and I just might have a solution to your problem."

One year and ten months ago...

"Oh my god!" Melanie's mother squealed, almost jumping the security checkpoint in her rush to grab her daughter in a bear hug. "Is that you, Mel? You look amazing!"

"Oof. Hi, Mom."

"I mean, you've lost so much weight! Alice, look at your sister!"

"Yeah, cool," Alice grunted, not taking her eyes off her handheld game system.

Melanie shrugged. "Well, they really give us a workout on the squad."

"But still! You must have dropped twenty pounds!"

"Just seventeen," Melanie grinned. "But it's great. It's a real supportive environment."

She looked down at Alice -- skinny little high-school Alice -- with a strange gleam in her eye. "In fact, they said they liked me so much, they were extending an open invitation to my family. When you girls get to college age... the Kappas will be waiting."

------

Five mules -- excellent ones, with quick metabolisms and lots of room to grow. They weren't all coming here, of course. Alice had just started school in New York. Melanie had noticed she hadn't been putting up many pictures of herself up lately, and the ones she did post were increasingly likely to be Fat Girl Angle Shots. Still, it had been quite a coup for Jenna. The higher-ups had been very impressed.

And what did Melanie get? She got to clean up after the rest of these hogs. She snorted in disgust.

"No, nothing's bugging me," she said. "I'm fine. Just fine."
1412111112.title: Melanie's Story

choices: They shut the door and leave, leaving Dawn alone with clues and the statue
Ellen and Kelsey enter the room to straighten up before leaving . . .
14121111122.content:
Dawn nodded slowly, trying to give Melanie a look that said she knew something was going on and that it would be okay to trust her. Instead, Melanie didn't notice. Which was for the best. Dawn's earlier attempts at such a look met with confusion rather than confidence.

"All right," Dawn said. "But, you know, you can talk to me if anything's wrong. We're sisters now,"

Dawn wasn't sure if that came out as sarcastic. Melanie stopped cleaning for second and smiled.

"Thanks. I appreciate it," it sounded sincere, if sad.

Mel was a dead in for the moment, Dawn decided. The other girls were off in all directions. She didn't hear anything from anywhere else in the house. She had an idea. An investigative idea.

"I'm going to go check out the library. I'll see you later, 'k?"

"Sure. Good luck, those are some dense books there. I could never get into them. But I'm sure you won't have any trouble," Melanie went back to cleaning with a grin.

Dawn found the library towards the back of the building. There was a well-marked exit, and next to it a cellar door leading downwards. It looked less creepy than last night as the girls led her down to that room.

The door was open slightly. Otherwise, it would have been easy to miss. It wasn't exactly hidden, but it matched the antique wood walls of the library room, and could be mistaken for just another wood panel. She opened it and went down, the creek it made less startling than if it had been the dead of night.

Inside was another story. She went down the well stairs, at least a full story, two stories below the surface. When the stairs ended Dawn shivered. The air down there was chilled. Nothing inherently supernatural about that, Dawn told herself. She asked herself why she was trying to deny something mystical was happening before realizing she was just getting very nervous.

A short stone hallway led to another, older wooden door. Dawn held her breath and stepped in. This was the room she had been initiated in. There were lights, but she couldn't find a light switch. Now that she was away from the stairway any light from outside had vanished. She took a few hesitant steps, then took out herself cell phone, holding it in front of her to at least get a little light.

So this is why they only remember to grab flashlights in horror movies, Dawn thought. Right now that's all she really needed. She could make out the stone floor, ancient and worn, the stone brick walls matching the well, some fixtures for torches on the sides, and a human-sized reddish monster with blank, evil eyes and a snarling, toothy mouth.

Dawn yelped and jumped back. Of course. The strange demon stature in the middle of the room, made from that stone that was also strange, and of no known demon species she was familiar with. But she knew people who were more familiar with more demons. She snapped a picture on her phone of the thing.

Maybe I'll get lucky and I'll find it in the books. Won't have to bother Buffy or Giles at all, wherever they are, Dawn thought. She really had gotten more self-sufficient since coming to college. She did her own laundry, got her own food, and investigated her own supernatural conspiracies.

The thought of food still made her a little sick. Dawn found herself lightly rubbing her still-full-though-less-swollen tummy as she noticed that the demon statue had quite a potbelly, too.

Then, footsteps from above. Echoing voices. One of Ellen's. The other was another girl Dawn remembered. Casey? Chelsea?

" . . . everyone knows I don't lock the door, Kelsey," Ellen said as they voices approached from above.

"Everybody doesn't know that. That's a dumb to thing to know anyways," Kelsey said.

"Jeez, what is with everybody these days? We just scored three new mules--"

"Shhh! Not out in the open! What if one of them is around?"

"Well, they wouldn't be hanging out down here, that's for sure. Besides, I saw them in the guest room like an hour ago. Asleep and bloated, as they should be."

Dawn heard the door swing shut, followed by the clanking of metal on metal. They're locking the door! she realized. She fought the impulse the sprint for it, to shove the door open, but realized it was already probably too late. And she was in no condition to be running, anyway.

She heard the voices, already muffled by the heavy door, fade as the girls left.

Now what?, she thought.

In retrospect, she might have been better off getting caught after all, she realized. That lock on the door seemed kind of ... final. She didn't think they came down here very often. What if she were stuck down here until the next time they showed up with pledges.

She rubbed her full stomach. Well, at least I won't starve...

Her blood ran cold at the thought. Starve, hell, if I'm stuck down here for very long I'll be as big as a house! Already, she was sure she was fatter. She pictured the Kappas shoveling in junk food, and her stuck in the basement, getting bigger and rounder with every passing day...

That is, unless they though to check this room when they noticed she was missing. Then they'd probably just do something horrible to her, like dress up in hoods and stab her with a big curvy dagger. That was one thing Buffy had mentioned about these demon cults -- they really liked their hoods and their daggers.

Inch by inch, she passed the pale light of her phone over everything in the room. The statue wasn't any prettier on closer inspection. It still looked like a grotesque, bloated demon, just closer up and uglier. At its feet were a few worn coins she didn't recognize and a small leatherbound journal.

Dawn pocketed the journal. "Just borrowing," she hastily told the statue, patting it on one rough cloven foot. It felt like metal in the sun on a summer's day, so hot it almost hurt to touch. She quickly drew back her hand.

The statue wasn't coming to life or anything like that, but she got the sense that whatever this thing was, this gross creature depicted in the statue, it was very close by, and it was watching her.

"Don't suppose you'd be willing to just let me out?" Dawn mused, half to the statue, half to herself. To her surprise, she got an answer.

"Don't suppose you'd be willing to give me something in return?" coughed a dusty-sounding voice. This was followed by a hacking cough and what sounded like the beginnings of an avalanche, as if something were expelling pebbles from its windpipe. For a moment, Dawn though she saw the stone features move, but when she looked again, the lips were frozen in the same sneering grimace, displaying a row of teeth more finely carved that anything else on the statue.

"Uh," Dawn spoke up, "uh, uh, what do you want?"

"Well," rasped the voice, "it would have to be something pretty good, wouldn't it? I'm fairly certain you're not exactly heading up there to throw me a parade. More likely I let you out and you come back down here with a sledgehammer and smash up my icon, hmm?"

"Er..." Dawn said. This was fairly close to the truth, but she realized that saying it probably wouldn't be a good idea.

"On the other hand, I'm bored silly down here. I used to serve priestesses. Queens! Now I'm stuck in this moldy old cistern helping a lot of vapid bimbos keep their figures. You're the first one who's actually talked to me in over a hundred years."

"So... so you'll let me out?" Dawn said hopefully.

"I'll think about it," the statue said. "Maybe if you agree to find me another Receiver."

"A what?"

"A Receiver, a -- what those skinny halfwits call a mule. Do you know how much hard it is taking all those calories and cramming them into only three of you? It's like trying to pack luggage for a dozen people into one tiny suitcase, only that suitcase is your ass. Do that, and I'll yet you out."

"Sure, okay," Dawn said. "But you'll let me out first, right? I mean, not gonna find anyone down here."

"You agreed to that pretty quickly for someone who actually meant to do it," the statue said. "Let me make this clear: if I let you out and I don't have another Receiver by sundown today, I'll start packing everything into you until I have one."

Dawn gulped.

Dawn hesitated. Finding another receiver was just another way of saying to find a new member for the house. That meant finding another thin, pretty, unsuspecting freshman to be made into a fat suppository for sisters who were already more beautiful than necessary. She glanced around, hoping to find an open door that she somehow missed.

"Hurry up and make up your mind," the demon said. "You're a Kappa now, so you're supposed to find new members all the time. They're just really bad at it. I'm just giving you extra motivation and a way out. And anyways, if you're true Kappa material you'll be back to your old figure next year when you become a full fledged member. In the meantime, you're already growing. Why not make an effort to lighten the load and look good in your sisters' eyes?"

Already starting? Dawn's hands unconsciously moved to her stomach.

"No, this is just--" she was going to explain it away as the massive feast she had eaten last night, but when her hands met an unfamiliar softness she stopped. She looked and saw that her form-fitting sweater was a fitting her form along the bottom a little too well. She poked the tiny bulge under the waist of her jeans, noticing that it was starting to squish out all around just slightly. How much did that represent? Five pounds? One pound? Dawn really had no idea. And she was finding it less and less appealing to have to find out what even more would do to the rest of her body.

The demon chuckled at her response.

"You caught on so quick. Guess the Kappa flattery doesn't work on you so well. Of course, if they had a full compliment of receivers then this would be happening so slowly you wouldn't notice until much later. But, with only three, well . . ."

"All right, it's a deal," Dawn said it so fast she was surprised at herself. Only after did she start rationalizing this decision that she would have this place shut down and this demon done with before anyone got hurt. Maybe if she spent the day researching she could even figure out a way to stop them and not have to add another mule to the house. Yes, that was her plan.

Dawn still hadn't stopped holding her hand over her stomach. She really was trying to ignore the fact that she was afraid of what was happening to her, and pushing out any thoughts that suggested to her that she had made a deal with this demon just to save her figure.

"Thanks a lot," Dawn said. "I'll find somebody by midnight, no problem."

The demon tried a maniacal laugh, but stopped when it came out sounding cheesy.

Dawn's phone bleeped at her. While in the dead zone of the basement Tiffany had left her a message. The sisters were moving them in. They were already going over there. They were each getting their own rooms and everything. Dawn could swear Tiffany was sounding more enthusiastic by the minute about being a sorority sister.

"Heeeey, Dawn! This is Tiffany! We're gonna' move all of ours and Tamisa's stuff over to the house. You know we all get our own rooms since they have so many free ones and we're gonna' be right next to each other still so that's awesome! I'm so excited! I bet you're studying, right? It's okay! We might even be done by the time you're done, these girls can move really fast. If you want to reorganize your things in your room they can help with that, too! They're soooo good at moving things, it's incredible. Well, byyyye!"

Well, all her clothes still fit, of course she's still excited. Dawn thought.

Those Kappas could not only move in a hurry, but they did it silently. Dawn passed nobody while crossing campus on that Saturday afternoon. The dorms were mostly quiet. Her and Tiffany's room was nearly empty. Dawn didn't know whether to be impressed or disturbed. Their dressers and desks were already moved. A few unpacked boxes remained. Dawn checked their closet and found her clothes were still there. Good, she needed a change. She felt grimy after a night of gorging, sleeping in her clothes, and then being stuck in a demon lair.

It was unfortunately still too warm to put on a jacket, so Dawn settled on a clingy t-shirt. She didn't like the way it was stretched around her tummy. She especially didn't like the way even this pair of jeans was more snug than it should be. Her profile showed a clear little bulge on her stomach. Was her ass getting bigger? Did her face look fuller yet? Dawn didn't think so. It was a long time since Dawn looked at her self so long in a mirror. She had a very un-Dawnlike thought as she did so. She thought about how sexy she looked, how beautiful, and how much she dreaded anything changing at all. Even the tiny soft stomach she had now was becoming repugnant to her. She had a fleeting thought that this was the Kappa influence. That perhaps by being aware of their plans, any kind of subtle magic to make new mules ignore their weight gain had backfired on her, and she was becoming hyper-aware and hyper-sensitive. Sure, that Lindsey had ballooned up in just a few months without fully being aware, but she didn't know what was happening to her. Did the demon work this subtle magic on them, too, or was it a separate spell the Kappas cast to make it easier for them? Or, was Dawn also considered, was she just feeling guilty for agreeing to give the Kappas another victim just so she wouldn't have to get as fat?

She pulled herself away from her reflection. It was time to get to work.

Dawn looked around the cafeteria. There were so many potential new Kappas, she felt like a kid in a candy store. She shifted in her seat, unable to get completely comfortable with the way her jeans were pinching her.

Make that a kid the day after the candy store..., she thought.

The problem was, it was easy to come up with justifications why it wouldn't really be so bad to invite this girl or that into the Kappas for a little while, but it was just as easy for her to find the flaws in her own reasoning. She felt like she had a little angel on one shoulder and a devil on the other, just like in cartoons.

"What about that girl?" suggested the devil. "She's dressed for basketball. She's an athlete. She'll work off the pounds in no time."

"No!" said the angel. "She could get kicked off the team. Do you really want that on your conscience?"

"Well, what about her? She's skin and bones," the devil continued. "Probably anorexic. Why, you might be saving her life!"

"At the cost of destroying her psychologically," the angel pointed out. "You know very well what something like that would do to someone already suffering from body image issues."

"Then how about that fat girl over there? Nobody said she had to start out thin. I mean, she probably wouldn't even notice twenty or thirty more pounds, right?"

"For shame! At her size, more weight could endanger her health!"

And so on. There just was no girl she could bring herself to subject to the Kappa treatment.

She'd only bought a few carrot sticks to nibble on, but as she shifted position she realized that she was becoming very full. The others must be having lunch, she thought. And as usual, not showing an ounce of restraint. That strengthened her resolve. If she didn't do something, it would be her subjected to even more of the Kappa treatment -- at least finding another girl would help mitigate things a little.

She scanned the room again. There! A slender girl carrying a large tray of pasta and garlic bread, with a thick slab of chocolate cake on the side. She was perfect! Obviously, she had a great metabolism. She wouldn't gain more than five pounds, Dawn was sure of it.

"And how sure are you that you can do something to stop the Kappas?" the angel wondered aloud. Dawn told it to shut up and hurried over to intercept the girl.

"Hi, uh, excuse me, I couldn't help but notice... "

Dawn looked the girl up and down. She was pale and freckled, about as ginger as it was possible to be, and her long red hair was held back loosely in a clip. She was short, maybe under five feet, and not quite as thin as Dawn had assumed at first. Maybe even a little chubby.

"Short people put on weight really easily--" began the angel, but Dawn shushed it again and took a good look at the girl's clothes, trying to find any clue she could latch onto. Cute white capris. A powder-blue T-shirt with a silhoette of a sailboat on it. Good enough.

"...I noticed you were interested in sailing, and my sorority, the Kappas, has been thinking of, um, buying a boat, you know, to go boating. So we're looking for girl who are, you know, into sailing. To teach us."

"Oh, well," the girl said, blushing. "I don't know the first thing about sailing, really. This is just a shirt."

"Oh." Dawn said. She really didn't want to let this one get away. She already felt so stuffed she doubted she could sit down again without taking off her pants. "Um... do you want to join anyway?"

The girl brightened. "The Kappas? Sure, I heard they were great! Do I need to, I dunno, interview with somebody or something?"

Dawn put a hand to her mouth to stifle a belch. "Oof. No, you're in. We can head over and get your inducted now." Her stomach gurgled, and she winced. "Right now.... uh... what's your name?"

"Randi," the girl said, grinning. "Let me just set this tray down."

"You can bring your lunch."

Randi laughed. "What, this? This isn't mine! I was just grabbing seconds for Amanda." She nodded her head towards the portly girl Dawn had considered earlier. "I wish I could eat like that!"

"What -- what do you mean?" Dawn asked.

"Only that if I ate all that, I'd probably weigh about a bazillion pounds!" Randi said fervently. "I barely have to look at fattening food and I just put on weight like crazy! I heard the Kappas are pretty good at keeping their members thin, though..." She giggled. "Maaaaaybe I'd be only grabbing a brownie. Gosh! The Kappas! I'm so happy, I could just burst!"

Jenna's managing had a lot to do with it. But they knew they couldn't complain. Their lives and figures would be on the line if they crossed the already overstressed Jenna.

---------------------

Well, that was a photo finish, Dawn thought, stifling a belch despite being alone, reading, in her new sorority room. She could tell some of the girls weren't pleased at Randi. "These girls are so nice it's ridiculous," Randi said. "They moved all my stuff right away! Can you believe it? I'm so glad you asked me to join. I just know this is where I ought to be."

"What's wrong? Did I do something wrong? Did one of the girls say something about me?"

Randi laughed, assuming Dawn's expression was just horrible gas.

"Excuse me," Dawn said meekly, and before she could get another word out Randi was talking again and going in her room to put up clothes. Dawn followed to help.

"Oh, these girls love their food," she patted her own stomach, "I'm absolutely stuffed! They'd better teach us their secrets to staying so thin soon or I'm going to blow up."

"Oh, uh, no you won't--" Dawn stammered.

"Yes I will," Randi giggled. "You didn't know me in high school. I was like 250 pounds until my senior year. I just decided to get healthy and work at it--really, really work at it--and here I am! Who would have thought I'd ever fit in with the Kappas?"

What would Buffy say if she knew I put someone in danger like this? To save myself? Worse, just so I wouldn't get fat? Still, I can't let this body go without a fight--

She shook her head to stop that train of thought. That wasn't like her. The Kappas might not be intentionally messing with her mind, but it certainly felt like they were, stuffing her day in and day out supposedly without her knowledge. She knew her sister wouldn't give an innocent up to a crazy fattening cult even if it did mean she'd be doomed to a life of obesity.

"--normally go the movies on Sunday with Amanda but she can probably come, if you want to go, and there's probably more sister stuff to do I can get settled in with the sorority life. This is all so new to me! Dawn? Did you hear me?"

"Actually she just asked if I'd like to join, and we came right over. Isn't that great?" Randi said.

Sure, there were words, but there were too many of them. The parchment-like paper shimmered like a hologram with handwriting overlaying other handwriting, as if it had been written and rewritten dozens of times.

Maybe it's like those magic eye books from the 90s. Only by holding it at a certain angle was Dawn finally able to make out the most recent entries. It was written in a blue ballpoint pen. Nothing special about that. The date was over two years before, and it was an oath.

"I, Jenna Greene, take the office of head of this chapter with the honest intent to do everything in my power to further the goals of all my fellow sisters, in this and every house."

She signed and dated it. The text now fully in focus, Dawn read the first entry, a terse account of how Jenna came to replace to former head . . .

She was beautiful, and like all Kappas took great pride in that, and so the punishment she had been dealt was all the more horrible. She was only trying to help the house. She was always trying to help. But that incompetent bitch Lucy didn't care. She was so full of herself, so concerned with her own short-sighted desires that she was was letting this chapter fall into ruin. Membership was down to a record low. Pledges were leaving as fast as they could find them, and that meant lowering their standards, which meant less and less pledges.

Jenna also knew, as did the other girls, that Lucy wasn't just derelict of her duty, but she had been stealing from the sorority coffers all year.

Jenna was going to let it go. Lucy would be gone by the end of the year, and Jenna was a shoe-in for the new head. Except that Lucy had forced her hand by punishing her like this, and only for going over her head to organize fund-raising and pledge-recruiting functions.

Jenna's stomach moaned. She pressed her hands into. She could already feel the fullness of the entire house of sisters descending upon her. She cried softly. With a grunt she tore off her jeans and her shirt, putting on frumpy sweatpants and a baggy hoodie. If she was going to balloon up before her eyes she did not want to feel her clothes growing tighter, her buttons popping, her shirt riding up to expose what was becoming of that flat, sexy stomach.

She rubbed her eyes. She had to work fast. She had a few calls to make.

Melanie and Ellen came by hours later. By then Jenna was just biding her time. She was lying on her back, her eyes closed, trying to ignore the creaking sounds her expanding body kept making. A layer of fat had swelled out all over her body, but her stomach was so stuffed that it was almost rock hard to the touch, and rose up past her now bloated breasts like a medicine ball. Occasionally a great rumbling would cause her to shift, and the way the fabric of her sweats rubbing against her reminded her that her hips were far too wide, that she didn't even want to see her ass now, and that even her arms were thicker.

"Can we come in, Jen?" Ellen asked.

"No," Jenna said. She tried to sit up, but the effort required depressed her, and so she stayed in her lying position.

"Lucy said she'll only keep you as the mule until midnight. But she probably has something . . . embarrassing planned for you, you know, when you come out tomorrow," Melanie said. "But, hey, it's only like thirty pounds, right? Not much more than that?"

Dawn must have skimmed a dozen journals of college girls--did she sound that whiny in her diary, Dawn wondered--and noticed a distinct pattern.

Thin girl joins. Thin girl gains a lot of weight. Thin girl leaves.
